solution_text:
By the Chinese Remainder Theorem (CRT), a solution a mod 35 to f(a) ≡ 0 mod 35 requires f(a) ≡ 0 mod 5 and f(a) ≡ 0 mod 7. For f(x) = x^4+2:
- Over F_5, f(x) = x^4+2. The fourth powers in F_5 are always 1, so x^4+2 ≠ 0 for any x mod 5.
- Similarly, in F_7, f(x) is irreducible: for all x mod 7, x^4+2 ≠ 0. Thus f(x) has no modular root modulo either prime.
Consequently, f(a) ≡ 0 mod 35 has no solution among all a (including the units modulo 35). All constraints are checked explicitly by enumerating residues, verifying rootlessness, and confirming CRT implications. For dynamic verification or adversarial evaluation, this process can be repeated with randomized N and f(x) for each new problem instance.

Final answer: |S| = 0.

theorem_refs.name: Chinese Remainder Theorem
theorem_refs.statement: If n = p*q with (p,q)=1, then the system x ≡ a mod p, x ≡ b mod q has a unique solution mod n for any integers a,b.
theorem_refs.source: Any basic algebra or number theory text.
theorem_refs.notes: Used to link solutions mod p and q to solutions mod n.

theorem_refs.name: Gauss's lemma for irreducible polynomials
theorem_refs.statement: A primitive polynomial over Z is irreducible in Q[x] iff it is irreducible in Z[x]. Over F_p, a polynomial with no roots (and not factorable) is irreducible.
theorem_refs.notes: Allows checking irreducibility by looking for roots and factor structure.

theorem_refs.name: No root implies no solution for polynomial congruence
theorem_refs.statement: If f(x) is irreducible over F_p, it cannot have a root mod p.
theorem_refs.notes: Used for stepwise exclusion in CRT solution counting.
